com.camerontec.util.logger.hpl.io

Class OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.camerontec.util.logger.hpl.io.OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer

  • public final class OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer
extends Object
    Class capable of playing HighPerformanceLogEvents from a high performance logger directory.

    Unlike the TailingHighPerformanceLogPlayer this implementation is capable of playing only the events from the specified directory that exist at the time of invocation.

    Programmatic consumers have access to the timestamp and offset information contained in each HighPerformanceLogEvent that is played. That is, programmatic consumers are expected to be able to keep track of where they're up to and be able to supply the timestamp and file offset of the last event received in order to resume a discontinued playback session.

    Nonetheless, event listeners must be able to handle duplicate events as it is always possible to stream from the start.

    See Also:
    TailingHighPerformanceLogPlayer

    • Constructor Detail

      • OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer

        public OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer(File directoryHandle,
                                       long timestamp,
                                       IHighPerformanceLogPlayerListener listener)
        Constructor.

        High performance log events from the specified high performance log directory and starting position will be played back.

        This constructor variant allows log playing to commence from an event specified only by timestamp. The rules governing this are:

        • If timestamp is ≤ 0L then log playback commences at the first available log event
        • If timestamp is > 0L then log playback commences at the first available log event with a timestamp ≥ to timestamp.
        Parameters:
        directoryHandle - The high performance log directory. Must not be null, must exist and must be a directory.
        timestamp - The timestamp of the log file entry prior to the required starting entry. Both timestamp and offset are ignored unless timestamp is positive and logs are played from the start of the first available log file. Note also that the timestamp may not be in the future as that open the possibility of selectively skipping log events which have not yet occurred and that is not supported.
        listener - The listener via which high performance log events are played back. Must not be null.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If any parameter is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified directory is invalid or if no starting file corresponding to the specified timestamp and offset can be found.

      • OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer

        public OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer(File directoryHandle,
                                       long timestamp,
                                       long offset,
                                       IHighPerformanceLogPlayerListener listener)
        Constructor.

        High performance log events from the specified high performance log directory and starting position will be played back.

        Parameters:
        directoryHandle - The high performance log directory. Must not be null, must exist and must be a directory.
        timestamp - The timestamp of the log file entry prior to the required starting entry. Both timestamp and offset are ignored unless timestamp is positive and logs are played from the start of the first available log file. Note also that the timestamp may not be in the future as that open the possibility of selectively skipping log events which have not yet occurred and that is not supported.
        offset - The offset in the log file of the entry prior to the required starting entry. If the specified offset is < 0L then it is not considered when determining the first event to be played back. That is, only the timestamp is used. If the offset is ≥ 0 then it is considered when determining the first event to be played back and in that case there must be a log event exactly matching timestamp and offset otherwise an exception is thrown.
        listener - The listener via which high performance log events are played back. Must not be null.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If any parameter is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified directory is invalid or if no starting file corresponding to the specified timestamp and offset can be found.

      • OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer

        public OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer(File directoryHandle,
                                       long timestamp,
                                       long offset,
                                       IHighPerformanceLogPlayerListener listener,
                                       UnaryPredicate<Void> stopCondition)
        Constructor.

        High performance log events from the specified high performance log directory and starting position will be played back.

        Parameters:
        directoryHandle - The high performance log directory. Must not be null, must exist and must be a directory.
        timestamp - The timestamp of the log file entry prior to the required starting entry. Both timestamp and offset are ignored unless timestamp is positive and logs are played from the start of the first available log file. Note also that the timestamp may not be in the future as that open the possibility of selectively skipping log events which have not yet occurred and that is not supported.
        offset - The offset in the log file of the entry prior to the required starting entry. If the specified offset is < 0L then it is not considered when determining the first event to be played back. That is, only the timestamp is used. If the offset is ≥ 0 then it is considered when determining the first event to be played back and in that case there must be a log event exactly matching timestamp and offset otherwise an exception is thrown.
        listener - The listener via which high performance log events are played back. Must not be null.
        stopCondition - Function called after each event is output, indicating whether playback should stop.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If any parameter is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified directory is invalid or if no starting file corresponding to the specified timestamp and offset can be found.

      • OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer

        public OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer(File directoryHandle,
                                       int tailFromNthEvent,
                                       IHighPerformanceLogPlayerListener listener)
        Constructor.

        High performance log events from the specified high performance log directory will be played back from the specified nth event from the end.

        Parameters:
        directoryHandle - The high performance log directory. Must not be null, must exist and must be a directory.
        tailFromNthEvent - The number of events from the end to play back.
        listener - The listener via which high performance log events are played back. Must not be null.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If any parameter is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified directory is invalid or if no starting file corresponding to the specified parameters can be found.

    • Method Detail

      • main

        @Deprecated
public static void main(String[] args)
        Deprecated. Use ViewLogs.main(java.lang.String[]).
        Main entry point.

        Usages:

        1. OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer - plays all log events from the current directory
        2. OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer [directory] - plays all log events from the specified directory
        3. OfflineHighPerformanceLogPlayer [directory] [timestamp] [offset] - plays log events from the specified directory after the event with the specified timestamp and file offset.
        Parameters:
        args - The program arguments.

      • play

        public void play()
        Play all log events from the starting position implied during construction.

        Event playback occurs synchronously in the thread of the caller. That is, on return from this method the caller may assume that all existing events have been played back.

        Note that programmatic consumers have access to the timestamp and offset information contained in each HighPerformanceLogEvent that is played. That is, programmatic consumers are expected to be able to keep track of where they're up to.

        See Also:
        HighPerformanceLogEvent.getTimestamp(), HighPerformanceLogEvent.getFilePosition()
